title: mingw: abi change on recent gcc
body:
Win32's cdecl callconv is different from linux's cdecl on returning large structs. For example (from [test suite](https://github.com/mozilla/rust/blob/master/src/rt/rust_test_helpers.cpp#L137)),

``` C
struct TwoU64s {
    uint64_t one;
    uint64_t two;
};

TwoU64s rust_dbg_extern_identity_TwoU64s(TwoU64s u) {
    return u;
}
```

On linux or mingw (gcc <=4.6), the function ends with:

``` asm
ret    $0x4
```

This means callee cleans stack for extra space. However, msvc (cl.exe) treats it differently:

``` asm
ret
```

then caller is expected to clean 4 bytes.
This implies it will hurt stack if mingw caller calls msvc function.
It is [a known issue](http://www.angelcode.com/dev/callconv/callconv.html), and is [reported at gcc bugzilla](http://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=36834) and [at mingw](http://sourceforge.net/p/mingw/bugs/1210/).

However, mingw's recent gcc follows win32 convention. (mingw-w64's gcc 4.8 also does.)
This is good for msvc compatibility, however it causes `make check-fast` failure on latest mingw:

```
task <unnamed> failed at 'assertion failed: `(left == right) &&
(right == left)`
(left: `t_317::TwoU64s{one: 98784247808u64, two: 257698037760u64}`,
right: `t_317::TwoU64s{one: 22u64, two: 94489280535u64}`)',
C:\home\stone\rust-vanilla\src\test\run-pass\extern-pass-TwoU64s-ref.rs:27
make: *** [i686-pc-mingw32/test/run_pass_stage2_driver-i686-pc-mingw32.out]
Error 101
```

Relevant codes are: [extern-pass-TwoU64s-ref.rs](https://github.com/mozilla/rust/blob/master/src/test/run-pass/extern-pass-TwoU64s-ref.rs), [rust_test_helpers.cpp](https://github.com/mozilla/rust/blob/master/src/rt/rust_test_helpers.cpp#L137).

(Well, to build rust with latest mingw, you need some hacks: [1](https://mail.mozilla.org/pipermail/rust-dev/2013-September/005562.html), [2](https://mail.mozilla.org/pipermail/rust-dev/2013-September/005567.html).)

I think we should follow msvc's calling convention on Win32. It implies that we (and bors) have to upgrade mingw later.
